Formula_1: $ {\Large\int_{a}^{b}} f(x) dx \approx \dfrac{b-a} {2n} {\Large\{} f(a) + f(b) + 2 {\Large[} f(x_1)+...+f(x_{n-1}){\Large ]} {\Large\}} \text { where } a=x_0 \text{ and } b=x_n $

Comment: ln a is a constant therefore can be removed from the integral it can go on the other side of the intergral equation when compared to the derivative equation.

This formula is not really needed on formula sheet as original function can easily be rewritten as $\dfrac{ln \thinspace f(x)}{ln \thinspace a}$ where $\dfrac{1}{ln \thinspace a}$ is a constant therefore the derivative rules for $y=\text{constant }\times ln \thinspace f(x)$ can be followed.  No equivalent integral is provided on formula sheet but can be easily derived.
Note the minus in front of fraction. Why no integral equivalent?
No square root as per inverse sin and inverse cos derivatives and plus sign
No square root as per inverse sin and inverse cos derivatives and plus sign
